user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 14.3 is: Controlling expressions shall not be invariant.
Here are exceptions to this rule:
1. Invariants that are used to create infinite loops are permitted.
2. A do-while loop with an essentially Boolean controlling expression that evaluates to false and satisfies the constraints and semantics for an integer constant expression is permitted.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_ForEachFilterCreator:
```c
bool OS_ForEachFilterCreator(void *ref, const OS_object_token_t *token, const OS_common_record_t *obj)
{
    OS_creator_filter_t *filter = ref;

    /*
     * Check if the obj_id is both valid and matches
     * the specified creator_id
     */
    return (OS_ObjectIdIsValid(obj->active_id) && (OS_ObjectIdEqual(filter->creator_id, OS_OBJECT_CREATOR_ANY) ||
                                                   OS_ObjectIdEqual(obj->creator, filter->creator_id)));
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function OS_ForEachFilterCreator:
static inline bool OS_ObjectIdIsValid(osal_id_t object_id)
{
    osal_objtype_t objtype = OS_ObjectIdToType_Impl(object_id);
    return (objtype > OS_OBJECT_TYPE_UNDEFINED && objtype < OS_OBJECT_TYPE_USER);
}
...
static inline bool OS_ObjectIdEqual(osal_id_t object_id1, osal_id_t object_id2)
{
    return (OS_ObjectIdToInteger(object_id1) == OS_ObjectIdToInteger(object_id2));
}
...
#define OS_OBJECT_CREATOR_ANY OS_OBJECT_ID_UNDEFINED
...
typedef struct
{
    osal_id_t        creator_id;
    OS_ArgCallback_t user_callback;
    void *           user_arg;
} OS_creator_filter_t
...
typedef struct OS_common_record OS_common_record_t
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: No controlling expressions (if, while, for, do-while, switch) are present in the provided code fragments. The only conditional-like code is the boolean return expression in OS_ForEachFilterCreator, which composes calls to OS_ObjectIdIsValid and OS_ObjectIdEqual; these functions compute their results from input parameters (object_id, creator_id) and are therefore not invariant. The helper functions shown (OS_ObjectIdIsValid and OS_ObjectIdEqual) return values derived from their arguments (via OS_ObjectIdToType_Impl and OS_ObjectIdToInteger), so their results are not constant at compile time. The macro OS_OBJECT_CREATOR_ANY is a constant, but its use is within a value comparison, not as a controlling expression for a loop or branch. Consequently, there are no invariant controlling expressions to investigate under MISRA C 2023 Rule 14.3 in the provided code.
